HistoryAnomalyDetection.title: HistoryAnomalyDetection
HistoryAnomalyDetection.name: HistoryAnomalyDetection
HistoryAnomalyDetection.overview: This algorithm trains on historical sensor data, after training new samples are compared to the trainings-data and than graded with an Anomaly-score between 0-100. An anomaly-score of 0 means the data is behaving normally. A value of 100 indicates a highly abnormal behaviour of the observed data. Usually a score above 15 means that an Anomaly has been observed, but this also depends heavily on the sensor data.

table.name: Add Variable
table.description: Adds a Variable which shall be monitored by the Anomaly Detector, max 10 variables

table.name: Unit
table.description: Unit of the variable which will be displayed on the chart [OPTIONAL]

table.name: var
table.description: Name of the Variable [OPTIONAL]

table.name: agg
table.description: Aggregation type of the Variable

table.name: type
table.description: Type of the chart scaling

table.name: heartbeat
table.description: The Anomaly Detector generates a heartbeat. The value switches every 60 seconds between 0 and 1, this indicates that the service is still active.

table.name: errorWarning
table.description: Error/Warning State from the Anomaly Detector

table.name: mpcReady
table.description: This variable indicates whether the Anomaly Detector is ready or not.

table.name: anomalyScore
table.description: Output mapping of the detectors anomaly score, gets written every minute

table.name: Threshold
table.description: The threshold at which data points are marked as anomalies, good default = 15

table.name: StartDate
table.description: Start date of the historic data

table.name: EndDate
table.description: End date of the historic data

StreamAnomalyDetection.title: StreamAnomalyDetection
StreamAnomalyDetection.name: StreamAnomalyDetection
StreamAnomalyDetection.overview: This algorithm takes in live-streaming sensor data and outputs an anomaly-score between 0 and 100. An anomaly-score of 0 means the data is behaving normally. A value of 100 indicates a highly abnormal behaviour of the observed data. Usually a score above 15 means that an Anomaly has been observed, but this also depends heavily on the sensor data.
